multiple.question: What does the line labeled S2 show?

content.instruction:
• Percentages and Changes in Percent
  • Dividing by Decimals
  • Calculate GDP and Price Indexes
  • Calculate Rates of Inflation
  • Nominal and Real Interest Rates

hotspots.hotspot:
Unemployment Rate

The percentage of the labor force that is unemployed

Unemployed

The number of people who are not working, but who are actively looking for work

Labor Force

The total number of people who are willing and able to work; it is a sum of both employed and unemployed workers

X 100

Multiplying by 100 converts the answer from a decimal to a percent

scene.matchingInstructions: Match the items on the left to the correct areas on the right.

matches.match: Government owns major industries, such as oil and gas.
Teens can decide whether to work or go to college.
The total hours a person can work is regulated.
The government allows free trade with all other nations.
Prices are not regulated and can increase quickly.
Labor laws make it difficult to fire employees.
Government sets the prices on many essential goods.
Some people earn huge salaries, while others earn little.
Government provides free housing and health care.

scene.instructions: When you are done, check your results by clicking 'Check Answers.'

hotspots.hotspot:
Price

Price is the Y-Axis label. "Price" can be either the price paid by consumers or the price received by producers.

Quantity

Quantity is the X-Axis label. "Quantity" can be either the Quantity Demanded (Qd) or the Quantity Supplied (Qs).

Supply

Supply is the label for the upward-sloping supply curve. Producers are willing and able to produce more of a good when the price goes up.

Demand

Demand is the label for the downward-sloping demand curve. Consumers are willing and able to buy more of a good when the price goes down.

Equilibrium

Equilibrium is the intersection of supply and demand. This is the one location on the graph where both consumers and producers will be satisfied.

Equilibrium price (Peq)

Equilibrium price (Peq) is the price of the good at market equilibrium. This is also called the "market-clearing price," because at this price there is an equal number of producers and consumers. Any other price will result in a mismatch of buyers and sellers.

Equilibrium quantity (Qeq)

Equilibrium quantity (Qeq) is the quantity of the good that will be produced at equilibrium. All of the goods produced at this quantity will be sold.

scene.matchingInstructions: Match the items on the left to the correct areas on the right.
scene.instructions: When you are done, check your results by clicking 'Check Answers.'

hotspots.hotspot:
Antitrust Violations

The U.S. Department of Justice sued Microsoft for antitrust violations in 1997, saying Microsoft illegally required PC manufacturers to include Internet Explorer. Microsoft's action had effectively shut out a competitor.

Weights and Measures

The government requires that all weights and measures be uniform, such as a gallon of gas. This promotes fair competition because gas companies cannot profit by measuring "smaller gallons" of gas and charging more.

Insider Trading

The U.S. government prosecutes individuals who use inside information to buy or sell stock before the information is made public. This is an attempt to ensure that all buyers and sellers can fairly compete in the market.

Safety and Advertising

The U.S. government promotes competition by requiring all food manufacturers to publish their ingredients. The government also prohibits false advertising claims about food to ensure that consumers know what they are buying.

scene.credits: (tr)Don Bishop/Photodisc/Getty Images, (cl)Ingram Publishing/age footstock, (cr)Judith Collins/Alamy, (bl)Comstock/Jupiterimages, (br)FoodIgredients/Alamy, (bkgd)Maria Toutoudaki/Photodisc/Getty Images.

hotspots.hotspot:
Expansion

An expansion is a period of economic growth, so GDP is rising. During an expansion, a nation has low unemployment and increasing income.

Peak

A peak is the temporary high point in economic growth. At the peak, the economy has full employment, meaning there is no cyclical unemployment and most job-seekers can find jobs. Growth has stopped, however.

Recession

A contraction occurs when GDP is decreasing. In this phase, unemployment is increasing. Businesses lay off workers because consumers aren't buying as many goods and services. If a contraction lasts longer than two consecutive quarters, it is called a recession.

Trough

A trough occurs when GDP hits a temporary low point. Although unemployment is high, the economy is poised for a turnaround.

scene.credits: (tr)Don Bishop/Photodisc/Getty Images, (c)McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc., (bkgd)Maria Toutoudaki/Photodisc/Getty Images.

hotspots.hotspot:
Recession

Although there are always some workers unemployed, the number of job-seekers rises during economic downturns called recessions. The unemployed struggle to provide food, housing, and other necessities.

Inflation

Inflation, or rising prices, is a major problem in an economy. Periods of high inflation erode consumers' purchasing power and their confidence.

Monetary Policy

The Federal Reserve (or "Fed") can combat inflation by reducing the money supply. The Fed also tries to combat unemployment by increasing the money supply and lowering interest rates.

Fiscal Policy

During a period of high unemployment, Congress might spend money on a jobs program or cut taxes to encourage individual spending. During a period of high inflation, Congress might raise taxes or cut spending to take money out of circulation.

scene.credits: (tr)Don Bishop/Photodisc/Getty Images, (cl)Emile Wamsteker/Bloomberg/Getty Images, (cr)Tom Grill/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images, (bl)Siede Preis/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images, (br)John Aikins/Corbis, (bkgd)Maria Toutoudaki/Photodisc/Getty Images.

content.header: AP Microeconomics Exam and AP Macroeconomics Exam

hotspots.hotspot:
Multiple Choice

Your score is based on the number of questions you answer correctly. Points are not deducted for incorrect answers, so you should answer all of the questions, even if you do not know the answer.

Free Response

Notice how the question asks you to do several things: Identify, Illustrate, Label, and Show the effect. You get points for each part of the question you answer correctly. Consistency is important, and you may be awarded points for a consistent answer, even if it is not fully correct.

multiple.question: Economics is the study of how we deal with money.
Microeconomics examines the individual consumer or the individual firm.
Price is the y-axis label on a supply and demand graph.
A recession occurs when GDP is growing.
On the AP Exam, you should not answer the questions you do not know.
